node.title: Attacks on hospital staff trigger trial of body cameras
node.alt: body security camera close up, it looks like a little black box
node.description: Physical and verbal aggression towards Bendigo healthcare workers has prompted the trial of body cameras for the hospital's security guards.
node.content:
["Bendigo's biggest hospital is to trial body cameras on its security workers, as staff find themselves dealing with increasing physical and verbal abuse from patients.", "The month-long trial comes as staff at Bendigo Health, particularly paramedics and those in the emergency department, encounter more threatening incidents where security guards are being called on for help.", "The test is a collaboration between the\u00a0central Victorian hospital and Spotless, the security contractor.\u00a0", "\"Unfortunately, we're subjected in the emergency department to abuse on a regular basis. Much of that is verbal abuse, and that can be just as cutting in the long term for staff and have just as much effect if not more than physical abuse,\" said the emergency department's director Dr Simon Smith.", "He said the hospital is yet to determine exactly how the vision will be used, but it is likely to lead to improvements.", "\"But first and foremost, it's for the safety of the staff,\" he said.", "\"If ever needed to, we can go back to that footage, to further understand what happened at that time.", "\"It's possible the footage could be used for education and showing people what patients look like when they're drug-affected and abuse staff. Maybe there'll be other possibilities;\u00a0we can use it to do some behavioural modification.\"", "", "
Tim Fraser and Simon Smith are fed up with violence towards healthcare workers.\u00a0(ABC Central Victoria: Sarah Lawrence)
", "
Paramedics fed up
", "Ambulance Victoria Loddon Mallee Area manager\u00a0Tim Fraser said staff are fed up with issues around violence and aggression \u2014 and he is hopeful the cameras will make a difference.", "\"We have a zero-tolerance approach to violence and aggression towards paramedics,\" said Mr Fraser.", "\"At the moment we have a high workload, and our staff are under stress. To have to think about occupational violence as well, puts extra pressure on our staff as well.\"", "\"We want the staff to feel that we've got their back,\" added Dr Smith."]
